content.content: There do seem to be a confluence of conflicts of interests here. Strategic Finance members will be earning a significant salary from Lido, while also manually administering the purchase of stEth on behalf of MakerDAO and acting as a “Protector MetaDAO” with broad powers in collateral onboarding. Wrapped up in this, MakerDAO is being asked to consider a large Lido token purchase.

content.content: It is extremely common for contributors within the DAO to contribute to other DAOs and has been brought up both publicly and privately in the past. If you or anyone in the DAO would like to discuss this subject, I would request posting in the aforementioned linked thread where this was brought up. Many DAO members from CUs and Delegates alike participate in other DAOs which positively impact Maker, while some have even launched protocols that are direct competitors. There have also been Core Unit contributors that also served as Delegates, at the same time. Regarding Lido specifically, until Lido launches it’s own stablecoin and Maker launches it’s own staking as a service business, I don’t believe they are competing. Indeed, I believe the projects complement each other and having contributors active in both DAOs would only increase Maker’s success long term, especially once the End Game Plan passes in which MakerDAO will accumulate significant amounts of stETH.     CodeKnight:  There do seem to be a confluence of conflicts of interests here. Strategic Finance members will be earning a significant salary from Lido, while also manually administering the purchase of stEth on behalf of MakerDAO and acting as a “Protector MetaDAO” with broad powers in collateral onboarding. Wrapped up in this, MakerDAO is being asked to consider a large Lido token purchase.   I’m happy to address any concerns publicly or privately, but given the significance of this MIP I would request that such discussions occur in the previously linked thread. I have been discussing MetaDAOs with @rune for the past several weeks and we have discussed how the SFCU could fit within the End Game Plan - such discussions have been extremely fluid and continue to evolve. Given that Rune is a significant LDO holder, I also discussed the idea of part of SF providing services similar to what we perform for MakerDAO, for LidoDAO. Regarding the acquisition of stETH by MakerDAO - SF will still write proposals to the community in the event of the Endgame Approval MIP Set passing to seek community feedback for ensuring the DAO can acquire stETH at the best possible price. This is not something I have discussed with Rune, as he mentioned on the DVC call today, but sounds like something we could use DssKiln for. Related to the Protector MetaDAOs and collateral onboarding - we deeply appreciate the trust and autonomy to support the DAO with Rune’s sub-proposal to move forward with onboarding proposals that will help facilitate the Endgame Plan and Protector Clustering. There are some very exciting MIPs currently being drafted that we believe will provide the DAO with the resources needed to successfully launch the Endgame Plan and MetaDAOs. Throughout the onboarding process, we will be as transparent as possible and provide frequent updates to the DAO.

content.content: Firstly, to clarify a minor point: SF is not onboarding at Lido . We are developing Steakhouse Financial, a small DAO-to-DAO partnership with a mission to democratize complex information for a broad base of stakeholders. We envision this as a niche platform with a very small number of DAOs that grows organically, leveraging contributors and community members who are already on the inside, and for protocols we are invested in and care about deeply. This platform should allow embedded groups of passionate contributors to grow with their DAOs in a modular and scalable way that aligns incentives for all participants. Needless to say, it is not going to be a high-growth FAANG tech company that will one day compete with Maker. It is a group of DAO contributors with enough brain damage from working in the space who want to organize a little bit more than before. Wrapped up in this, MakerDAO is being asked to consider a large Lido token purchase.    Our first thought on stETH is to not operate it actively  We learned about this plan at the same time as everyone else, reading this post Based off our experience with Makershire, our instinct is to not actually take ownership of the buy order but run it through a permissionless vault, such as a PSM or DSS Kiln, where final decision authority would remain with token holders   None of us has any decision authority in either DAO, nor do we have enough tokens to make any sort of meaningful decision in any camp  General Comment: Often the tone of discussions at Maker is for things to happen then nothing happens then all of a sudden it blows up for some reason and outrage is produced. The Lido proposal has been on their forums and their twitter accounts for some time now. Often this outrage tends to be coordinated by anon accounts. While we are obviously welcoming of all identities who may not have the desire to dox themselves while interacting here, these interactions also tend to be very short on substance, some of whom have significant conflicts of interest themselves. With some notable exceptions incl. @iammeeoh despite his evident disappointment. Let’s have a discussion on the issues to resolve them diligently and leave outrage at the threshold. We’ll be on the G&R to discuss our Offboarding Proposal though I am certain there are far more pressing matters to talk about for Maker than one more round of human drama. This thread is meant to be about the Endgame Plan and we would appreciate getting back to the matter on hand, as well as moderator’s help in merging this with the External Work thread or, even better, a new thread altogether.

content.content: While my view might be unpopular, I think it’s allowable for a Core Unit contributor or contributors to engage in different roles. In fact, the Maker protocol allows even anonymous contributors who in theory the community doesn’t even know they are engaged in other entities / protocols. However, if the CU or the members are under performing because they have to juggle between different roles, then the community and the governance will take notice and take actions. I think for now, SF CU has been functioning well but you can imagine if the performance deteriorate in the future, they would be encouraged to readjust their prioritization.

content.content: I tend to agree with @Doo_StableLab’s comments. It’s notable in this case that SF used their same names/identities in their Lido proposal (a public post) even though nothing really would have stopped them from doing so under other identities, or consulting privately, etc. As Aes says, we do not require CUs to work exclusively for Maker and there are plenty of examples of other CUs doing work for other protocols. It would be unfair to hold SF to a standard we haven’t held any other CU to. If we want to  have exclusive workers at the DAO, that should be its own broad conversation on a DAO-wide scale, rather than assert some kind of implied fidelity/contract on an ad-hoc basis. The other point I would make, though, is that this general practice (of CUs contributing work to multiple DAOs) seems like the direction of travel in any case for Maker. Take the possible shift to Project-Based Budgeting, for instance, where contributors’ tie to Maker would presumably be to complete a discrete scope of work. The Endgame Plan also envisages most CUs working as contributors to autonomous MetaDAOs, at arms’ length from the core protocol. None of this means that conflicts of interest won’t exist in the future, but the very nature of Maker’s workforce is fluid and evolving, which seems like important context for this discussion.

content.content: Folks time to be real here on some basic issues.  As contractors to MakerDAO as far as I know CUs have never had to sign any form of non-compete agreement (which actually is common in a lot of tech companies for many reasons).   Not even sure who could co-sign on this for the DAO actually. Many companies now as a condition of employment restrict employees from being employed elsewhere.  This is less common than (1) but it is a growing trend as far as I know. If one looks at contractors for the DAO as consultants then one has to consider it natural for these contractors to solicit and work for other clients.   In fact if you think there will be high variability on the work for these people you sign them with a ‘retainer’ so they continue to be available over periods of time vs. them just deciding they no longer have to work for you.  It was always my expectation that CUs would and should start to look like MakerDAO spinoff business units (BUs).  MakerDAO until the MetaDAO concept never really grasped the idea, much less practically, how to do BUs.  Given the complete lack of jurisdiction and legal accountability between a DAO and anything (except RWA through a trust, etc.) I couldn’t see how MakerDAO could actually spin off BUs and retain ownership/control via ownership stakes.    The point here is why would Maker spend millions on CU contractors to effectively start their own BUs and not retain any ownership stakes? Rune seems to think MetaDAOs solve the above.  Time will tell. I come back to something @PaperImperium said over a year ago now and I am paraphrasing him.   DAOs are basically are the worst of all organizations I will add that Maker failing to home in any jurisdiction is equivalent to floating a pirate flag on its business ship. The real issue here is that MakerDAO contractors have no explicit rules for conduct and no jurisdictional or legal frameworks to fall back on should agreements be broken.  This involves disclosure of conflicts of interest, non-disclosure agreements, non-compete, etc. No matter what is decided here - one thing should emerge - a uniform and equal treatment of all MakerDAO individuals within particular classes (whether this is contractors, vault owners, DAI holders, delegates or MKR holders) which in the case of CUs as contractors will mean a general rules of conduct for contractors equally applicable to all contractors.

content.content: In general I completely agree and I definitely don’t think SF should be called out specifically for working for other protocols in general.  The cost/productivity/value of many CUs is obviously an issue for Maker as a whole and can/should be addressed separately. The issue here is that SF seems to be involved with the administration and (this part is not clear to me) possibly the strategic usage of a protocol that they are (or will be) getting paid by.  This is as if the US government hired a firm to manage a new fighter jet program and the firm they hired was also on Lockheed’s payroll (or if RWF was on HVBanks payroll).  That would be absurd and the firm could not be expected to neutrally carry out those duties.  If SF is getting paid by Lido, they should not be involved in purchasing assets that directly benefit Lido or in making strategic decisions/recommendations that directly benefit Lido.

Aes addressed this:      Aes:  Our first thought on stETH is to not operate it actively  We learned about this plan at the same time as everyone else, reading this post Based off our experience with Makershire, our instinct is to not actually take ownership of the buy order but run it through a permissionless vault, such as a PSM or DSS Kiln, where final decision authority would remain with token holders     (my stance, not representative of SF) Even if it was more active operation, there isn’t really room for a conflict of interest to be influential. All that is planned to happen is a DCA purchase of a preset amount of stETH at a preset cadence. How could execution of this possibly be influenced by a conflict of interest?

content.content: Maybe I’m misunderstanding Strategic Finance’s role in Maker or reading the name too literally.  Isn’t one of the CU’s core responsibilities to advise the DAO on these types of decisions (i.e. deploying $100 million+ into stETH)?

Some thoughts (personal, not representative of risk CU):  Echoing Matt, @juan’s post about project based budgeting seems relevant. What Maker really needs is quality work product and throughput, not FTEs per se (although I think having people who are “full time” committed to Maker has big, intangible benefits). Risk of the engagement seems low as SF actions must be thoroughly justified to pass governance, and SF team does not have the power to control protocol assets independently. If any conflict starts to emerge (eg favoring Lido at the expense of competitors or against the best interests of MakerDAO), I think this can be identified and corrected on a case by case basis, rather than preemptively based on the potential for future conflicts. Key DAO services may become cheaper over time if we let our CUs grow in scale by serving more organizations. Particularly in SFs case, I think generating financial statements and financial planning could benefit from supply side economies of scale. To the extent that DAI/MKR budgets are being justified to MakerDAO based on a certain number of FTEs, it does matter that these people are actually working for Maker full time. But in some cases the better solution may be rethinking our budget setting standards rather than discouraging work for external protocols. An alternative model for external protocol work is billing external protocols for benefit of MakerDAO (eg. risk team’s recent proposals at Aave and Compound included payments to MakerDAO). This may not work in all cases and maybe isn’t the best mechanism in the long run (eg would it be better for service providers / CUs to bill other protocols directly and be able to charge Maker less?) but worth considering.  Disclaimers:  I participated in LDO private sale last year and it remains one of my largest holdings I contribute to a few other DAOs (although generally not for pay)
